segments.text: And I also said that I don't know what happened.
I heard later that they got 10 or 15 years and the guy that used the machine gun once again didn't know what he was doing.
He was high on drugs so he wasn't responsible for his actions.
They had some good civil liberties union people in Bung Tao as GI lawyers.
I know every one of them must have been a card-carrying member.
What they should have done is thrown him out of the helicopter when they took him down.
Did that go on?
You know, I never did see anything like that.
Did you ever hear anything like that?
When I went to Pleiku in 1970, there was a big operation going on close to the Cambodian border.
And this was down close to a place called the Oasis.
There was a tank battalion there.
An NVA regiment had assaulted this tank battalion.
It was a tank company that was in defensive positions at the Oasis, which was an engineer base over on Highway 19.
And you can see the Chinooks.
It's a big helicopter.
It looks like a banana.
Coming back, and they had cargo nets slung on the bottom part of them.
And you just looked like they were carrying regular cargo until they got real close to you.
And then you could see the arms and legs sticking out of the cargo.
But they were bringing about bodies.
And then they'd put them in body bags and ship them home.
They had a major battle someplace.
But that's the only time that I'd seen anything like that.
I had heard that...
You know, sometimes when they were doing some interrogation work, that they'd carry a guy up in the helicopter, two guys up in the helicopter, throw one out and get the other to talk.
I never saw anything like that.
It's hard for me to comprehend that American soldiers would do something like that.
I guess it would be a good way to get a guy to talk to them.
But there were a lot of things that went on at the South Vietnamese to get people to talk.

I can tell you that if you take a silk scarf and you tie the guy down and you put the silk scarf over his face just to where it comes down and touches his nose and his mouth, if you pour water all over that silk scarf on the top of it to where it comes down and lays across the guy's face, it makes him think that he's suffocating and he can't breathe.
Captured a guy one time that was a tax collector.

And since I'd already been in Vietnam a year and a half, I knew that if I turned him over to the Army or the American forces, that the guy would be back out there in the next three or four weeks collecting his taxes again.
So I took him to a unit called the Mike Force.
Now, this Mike Force had...
little bit of Chinese.
Well, to give you an idea of their company commander was an Australian.
They had three or four Special Forces guys with them.
They had some Australian Special Forces people.
And then all their basic soldiers were Chinese privates.
Now these guys could take a magazine with 20 rounds in it and 16 and go anywhere in South Vietnam and nobody messed with them.
They were that bad.
And I took this guy down there.
And I gave him about 40,000 answers.
And I said, this man must be a tax collector.
I caught him on the road this morning trying to get into the village.
And I said, if I take him down here and I give him to anybody else, he'll just be back down here.
They said, well, we're going to be in the sheriff for a couple of weeks, so we'll talk to him.
Well, they talked to him.
They hooked him up to a telephone.
And the guy sang like a canary.
Got all the information they wanted to out of him.
cleaned that guy up, they put him in a suit, and took him into town and turned him over to the district check.
Then they went out and got everybody that he had put on their list and got everyone.
And I never saw that tax collector again.
And I felt good about doing that because he wasn't out there taking the people's money from him.
wasn't threatening him about to be seen.
Now, I know somebody else took his place, but he wasn't there.
And I thanked him for it.
I thought it was a good unit.
Well, what did you think of the Korean forces and the Australian and the, quote, allies, unquote?
Well, the Koreans, as far as fighting them, now let me just tell you,

The Koreans did everything in South Vietnam that we taught them how to do in Korea as far as building fire bases, how high the berm had to be, what type of Constantino wire you had to put out, what your firing positions were.
And you go over there, and they had two divisions there that I remember.
And to go up to An Cay from Quy Nhon, you had to go right past a rock division fire base.
They had one strand of bob wire.
around their outer berm.
One strand of bottom wire.
And they had little signs out there saying, please attack us.
And you know what?
They never got mortared.
They never got sniped at or nothing.

You go to the next fire base down the road, which is an American fire base, there must have been thousands of yards of concertina wire, claymore mines, and just everything in the world, and they get picked on all day long.
So it didn't matter what the American forces thought about the Koreans in South Vietnam.
What mattered was how the North Vietnamese and the B.C.
thought about the Koreans.
And they didn't fool with them.
The Koreans had to go out and beg the B.C.
to fight.
They were good soldiers.
They were good soldiers.
Probably the only mistake that we made is Lieutenant Calley and some of our lieutenants went to Vietnam a couple of weeks earlier.
And they worked with the Korean division.
And so when the American troops got there and Cali took over his platoon again and Captain Medina's coming, he wanted them all to be like the rocks.
You have to understand the Oriental mind.
And I don't think any white man will ever understand the Oriental mind.
It's a different concept of operation completely.
You know, MacArthur was one of the first guys that said, don't get involved in a war on the Asian landmass.
And why we continue to do that after we saw the French and the Chinese and everybody else there, you know, is beyond me.
Let me put in here at this time, in case we run out of film, that the American soldier on the average in South Vietnam was a dedicated soldier.
I feel that, and I guess it's because I had to feel that way about it.
Otherwise, the two years and the 20 years that I spent in the military would be wasted psychologically.
It would probably screw my brain up pretty bad.
I don't have any...
negative things about Vietnam, like Agent Orange or all this other crap that some of these people cop out with.
And I think that's what it is, is a cop out.
The second time I went to South Vietnam, it was evident to me that the American leaders and the American people were not going to let us win the war.
We were not going to be allowed to fight to win.
That's the reason they pulled us back to the fire bases and the bridges and say, you can operate within 1,500 meters of this road, but don't get 1,600 meters away from the road.
Those were the kind of units that you had in South Vietnam.
And this is getting back to the question that you asked me about drugs.
You take all these soldiers and you put them in one spot for a year and say, you can't move.
And the only time you're going to move off this bridge is when you go on R&R.
for seven days somewhere out of country.

Now you take a highly trained fighting guy that has gone through booby trap warfare and all this other crap back here in the States so he can stay alive when he gets to South Vietnam, and he never gets to utilize any of that training.
The guy's bored to death.
He sits there, and you can only shoot so many rounds at tin cans and stuff like that, you know, around your perimeter, around your bunker, and stuff like that.
And you get bored to death.
All these guys, a lot of them, would either start drinking liquor or they'd start smoking pot or they'd mainline heroin.
And that's when the drug scene really got bad in Vietnam.
You just didn't take guys out into the bush and fight the VC at their own game while they're high on drugs.
And the guys knew that.
So if they smoked pot at all,
It was back at the fire base.
You didn't do it out there where you were going to run into somebody who was going to try to kill you.
So the drug scene would be bad from 70 on until we got completely out of South Vietnam.
I left South Vietnam in September of 1971.
Never went back.
And I was teaching Russian doctrine at West Point in 1975.
in the fall of Saigon.
And there were a lot of guys in that department that just sat there and cried because of all the waste.
Fifty-four, fifty-five thousand guys.
A lot of them were friends.
Not to mention all the money and weapons and stuff that we left there for these little idiots to run around Southeast Asia with.
You know, we didn't blow everything up when we come out of there.
So I guess we all determined that while we were there, we did the best that we could.
And then after it was all over with, it was just part of your past and you put it behind you and you go ahead and drive on and get ready for the next one.
Do you think we could have won the war?
We could have kicked ass and took names over there so easy.
We could have put the 2nd Armored Division on Highway 1
We could have put the 1st Armored Division on Highway 19 and we could have told them to meet us in Hanoi in two weeks and we'd have won the war.
We weren't supposed to win the war.
The way I look at it now.
Why?
I don't know why.
I wish I did and I wish I could really get all the people that were responsible for it in the same room and so I could nuke them.
And he thinks responsible for it.
Well, the American leadership, for one thing, was responsible for it.
Kennedy, basically, I think, had the right idea by putting it back.
Trying to help the people win their own war.
Then it would have meant something.
When they started escalating and putting American GIs in there, and we took over the role of the South Vietnamese Army, that's when we made our mistake.
We could have went in there
and defended the airfields and stuff like that, and let the South Vietnam's Army be trained and be equipped by us and fight their war, then it would have been a civil war, okay?
We went in there and tried to intervene, and it was no longer just a North Vietnamese, South Vietnamese civil war.
It became a world situation.
The Russians were supplying the North Vietnamese.
We were supplying the South Vietnamese.
They had Russian advisors.
They had American advisors in Australia and anybody else that was supposed to be in the CTO to help us.
And we got overcommitted in something that we probably just shouldn't have even been there.
Why do you think we got involved in the first place?
To stop communism.
So do you believe Truman's theory?
Which is?
The domino theory, if one...

Yeah, I think one of these days that if we don't do something about South America, Nicaragua and down in that part of the country, that something will likely happen like this movie that came out several years ago called The Red Dawn, where they invaded through the Mexican area and through Washington State.
And then you end up fighting on your own country, in your own country, and you fight a guerrilla war.
Because everybody else around you has finally been cut off.
And all the fingers are cut off, and now the hand doesn't operate.
And I agree with that theory.
And there's a solution to it.
Okay?
We could have stopped communism in South Vietnam.
We could have won the war.
We won a lot of the fights.
You know, a lot of the battles.
The press were the ones that made the Tet Offensive a big
defeat for American soldiers.
For two weeks, they escalated the war.
And in two weeks, we had drove them all back.
We had killed maybe 50,000-something Little BC in NVA and regained all the territory that we had lost, if we lost any at all.
But the press made it a big defeat and a big psychological victory for the BC.
Why do you think the press is allowed such a free hand?
I don't know.
But... And you don't want to get me started talking about the press because I think they're all a bunch of communist pinko pigs.
Okay.
That's not a press question.
All right, you had said...
made some comments about the National Guard.
Do you think they should have been brought over to fight?
I don't see why.
I don't see any need for the National Guard to be called up unless it's the last.
You know, to me, the National Guard is going to be here to defend the homeland.
If the regular army can't take care of something someplace else, then you call up the National Guard and the Army Reserve, and then you get them involved in it.
I realize that there are specialized units, like special forces, some Air Force units, fighter jobs, and stuff like that, that you may need to infuse into the total program.
But to nationalize the National Guard, to go overseas to fight in South Vietnam, to me, was stupid.
I don't think they were needed.
I really don't.

There were enough original army units around that could have taken care of the situation if they would have been allowed to fight the way that we were trained and not to do this and don't do that and oh, you can't do this.
If we would have fought in South Vietnam like they fought World War II and World War I, we wouldn't.
How long do you think it would have taken them?
I don't know.
I don't think it would have took very long.
You would have had a lot of holdouts that would have been in the mountains and had guerrilla warfare.
But you can fight guerrilla warfare with counterinsurgency.
You go in and you take care of the guerrillas.
You don't go in and settle down in a village and wait for them.
You move into their area and you snipe at them and you ambush them and you take care of them and you fight the way they fight.
And eventually, you kill them all.

You don't get rid of the guerrilla fighter by going in and assaulting his women or burning down his village or things like that because every time you do something like that, for every one guerrilla that you kill, you've got ten more that's willing to join their army because you've hurt their family, you've burned up their hooch, you've destroyed their food and things like that.
But you can kill off the guerrillas.
Why do you think, or do you think we use
conventional warfare tactics against an army or the B.C.
that was so much guerrilla warfare?
I think basically your North Vietnamese army was conventional, and I think your B.C.
were the guerrillas.
And I think if we would have operated the same way, when we first got into South Vietnam, they said, oh, well, the knight belongs to Charlie.
Well, hell, the knight didn't belong to Charlie.
The knight belonged to whoever went out there and took it.
When we started our night ambushes and we started moving at night and engaging the VC at night, they quit moving around.
You know, you isolate them into certain areas.
And if you don't interdict trails 24 hours a day, and sometime during that day, Charlie's going to figure out what your sequence is and he's going to move.
But if you keep interdicting everything and you fight them when they fight, you're killing them.
What did y'all do when the VC didn't want to fight or the NBA didn't want to fight, just didn't?
We'd go look for them.
We'd pick out areas that had a lot of, we'd get a lot of intel out of it.
You know, you had five categories of intelligence.
The number one source was American ice, salt.
The number five was...
Some rice farmers we heard about said he saw so-and-so over here.
You know, that was the difference between the two.
So that's when they started sending out a lot of long-range patrols.
And that's when guys started going into the jungle and getting back in there and sneaking people and finding them, you know, where they were.
That's when you got your tunnel rats that started going into your tunnels and everything and going down and blowing up their holes and stuff.
somewhere they couldn't use them, and then they had to come out and build.
The defoliation program with Agent Orange.
You know, for what it was supposed to do, you know, kill all the trees and everything so you could see stuff walking around, it was great, but it was killing everybody else it touched, too.
You know, you've got a lot of guys out here that say that they breathed it or whatever it is, and now their kids have got cancer.
I don't know if any of that stuff is true or not.
I don't know if it's a bunch of guys just trying to get some more insurance or anything.
Frankly, if they get it, I think they got it coming to them because they were there.
But I don't think that was the way to fight the war.
We had enough guys that were trained to fight as guerrilla warfare people.
We could have, if nothing else, just flooded special forces people all over the country and trained the mountain yards.
The mountain yards hated the Vietnamese.
They didn't care if it was north or south.
If they were Vietnamese, they'd like to kill them.
You know, we could have trained all the mountain yards in South Vietnam, and they could have took over the country.
What is it?
Politics.
And I don't know enough about politics to talk about them, but I can tell you, somebody made wrong decisions to back their own people.
How about General Key?
Where's he at right now?
New Mexico?
Living high off the hog?
I know he's in the United States someplace.
He was the prime minister of South Vietnam.
Where does he get all this money?
What other credibility did the guy have except he was an Air Force general that we had trained, and he ran their Air Force for them, and then when we threw out them and his brother...
He took over the government.
Where'd he get all his money to live high on the hog out here in New Mexico or California?
You think some of it came from all that stuff that was supposed to go to the buildings for the classification that didn't make it?
I'd say so.
I'd say so.
Matter of fact, if it wouldn't be so bold, I'd say I'd stake my life on it.
About Jim and his brother, do you think we assassinated him?
We did?
No, we didn't.
The South Vietnamese Army did.
You think we helped set it up?
I don't know.
I would say so.
Why?
Just by the way that things ran in South Vietnam.
I think the CIA had their fingers in every little dirty thing over there.
And if they didn't, then Navy intelligence or Army intelligence or somebody knew what happened.
And they either knew it was going to happen and could have prevented it, or they participated in it.
You think this is the only case?
No, no.
I'm sure there was a lot of that.
You've got to understand now that I was just Staff Sergeant E6,
And I spent 11 months and 16 days in the bush until I hit the second evac hospital and got med evac'd.
Okay?
I stayed out in the field.
My bag wasn't politics.
It was staying alive and doing my job.
And I didn't get into the pot smoking or the beer drinking or anything else.
The only time I drank beer is when I went back to Hawaii on my own.
When did you get involved with the Special Forces?
Well, I got a little tied up with a guy named Major Hudson that I mentioned before.
He was with Charlie 75th Range.
And did some insurgent work with him because I was the operation sergeant for the camp, or the camp squadron that I was in.
helicopter resources that were available was through our cabinets.

Well after being there for about six months I was getting bored sitting around answering radios and stuff like that so I started flying and doing some insurgents and stuff with the retrieve commander of the helicopter unit and got to know Major Hudson pretty good and then started doing some penetration work with him as a team leader and operation sergeant for him.
you know, just sort of eased into it.
It wasn't hard.
All you had to do was be dumb enough to volunteer for different things, and people always accept you, you know.
I did that kind of work for about six months, and then the squadron commander called me into his office.
I was getting ready to rotate back, and I had an assignment at Fort Hood, Texas,
Lord have mercy.
And I would have extended another year in Vietnam to stay out in Texas.
And he said, how would you like to go to West Point?
And I said, don't you think I'm a little old to go to West Point?
And he says, no, you idiot, as an instructor, not a cadet.
Because I was already an E-7 and was on the E-8 list.
I said, well, I said, where's it at?
And I didn't know anything about West Point.
I knew that's where they had lieutenants come out of West Point, someplace in New York, and it's on the Hudson River and everything.
And he talked to me about it, and he said, well, the armored branch at West Point is looking for a noncommissioned officer to come up there and be an instructor.
And I said, I'd like to hear what he does.
And I said, hell, I'll do it.
So I got out of country two days early because they wanted me to spend a couple of weeks with the armored sergeant that was already at West Point.
I had a little overlap there between us so I could learn the job real good from him before he DD'd out of the area.
And I left Vietnam in September of 71 and went to West Point and I stayed there for five years.
I took the cadets down to Fort Knox every summer.
I taught your basic military science classes
small unit tactics, terrain interpretation, main navigation.
The last two years I was there, I got into Russian doctrine and started teaching some junior and senior classes in Russian.
I knew a lot about the Russian tactics.
And then from there, I went to 3rd Squadron, 2nd Camp in Germany, in a little town called Amberg.
I was 1st Sergeant for K Troop.
And I ran the border for three years.
and really enjoy it.
The same colonel came through on an IG inspection tour right before I got ready to be released out of Germany and said, how'd you like to go back to West Point?
And I said, well, you know, that's probably one of the best tours I've ever had.
I said, I'd like to go back there.
So in 78, October 78, my family and I went back to West Point.
Except this time we were living on Sergeant Major's Road.
And these were homes that were built in the late 1800s, and they were beautiful, and they had big fireplaces, and the ceilings were 11 foot high.
And I said, finally it arrived.
You know, I finally made it.
And I came out on the sergeant major's list.
I was supposed to go to Bliss, the sergeant major's academy.
And I said, whoa, I better call and find out where I'm going to go when I get out of the sergeant major's academy.
because I was due to be in there in January, and this is October.
So I called DA and I said, hey, Phil, I said, where am I supposed to go when I graduate from Sergeant Major's Academy?
He said, well, you're supposed to go to Germany.
I said, I just came back from Germany.
He says, I know, but he says, well, you'll do six months at the Sergeant Major's Academy.
We'll leave you there six months as an instructor, and then you can go back to...
You know, you'll have about another six months to wait before you get your sergeant major strike.
So we'll put you in a unit where we've got a sergeant major that's getting ready to rotate in six months, and then you just step right into his position.
I was tickled to death.
I loved Europe.
Because every year we'd take 20 days, and we'd just travel all over Europe and camp out and just do what we wanted to do.
I went home that evening and I said, guess what?
I'm on the sergeant major's list and we're going to do six months at Fort Bliss and then six months there as an instructor.
And then we're going back to Germany.
I ain't going back to Germany.
And I said, well, I'm not going back to Germany myself because if I go by myself, then that's two years that I have to do by myself and my family from the States.
So I called DA the next day and I said, hey, what are my options?
And he said, you've got two choices.
He says, you can go back to Germany when you get out and start a major academy, or you can retire.
Well, he upset me.
And I said, well, I'm going to take my models and I'm going home.
And I retired.
I've regretted it ever since.
I should have stayed in.
I have 28 years in now.
I'd be some fat old sard maker someplace in Europe in a guest house drinking cold beer and smoking a cigar.
What did you see happening in Vietnam while you were stateside between your tours?
Hmm.
Didn't really pay that much attention to it.
I just watched the news every day and tried to keep up with some of the old units that I was in.
I think it became...

I think after the initial Tet Offensive and it started settling down that things in Vietnam started changing from what a military man would consider okay to bad because you had to start asking for permissions to fire.
I think the involvement in South Vietnam changed after the Tet Offensive because they thought that...
You know, that American soldier got beaten bad during the Tet Offensive, and that wasn't the case at all.
I think it was just a matter of bad publicity as far as the military was concerned.
And I think people were just tired of it, didn't want us there, and it was time to either finish it up or get out.
What did you see happen with the United States government while you were stateside?
Well, I think more and more politicians were listening to their constituents and they were starting to turn the screws in different ways politically to get the troops out of South Vietnam.
I don't know.
It was just, uh,
Everybody at first was on the bandwagon and then rapidly started jumping off of it because they could see that it really wasn't what the public wanted.
I think it was just a difficult situation for political figures.
They didn't know which way to jump.
They couldn't make a decision.
And that was one of the reasons why the military figures in South Vietnam were not allowed to win the war.
Win the battles, but don't win the war.
And there was a lot of pressure on people to turn everything back over to the South Vietnamese.
Why do you think the government had this attitude of, okay, we'll let you in the bowels, but we won't let you in the war?
Why do you think they didn't want to go in and win?
Well, you know, it started out at first with just advisors, and then we built up a little bit because of the Gulf of Tonkin incident, and U.S. ships were fired on.
and we'll send the Marines in and protect the air bases.
And then it just sort of got escalated, and it got away from them.
And I don't know if it was because there were general officers in South Vietnam saying, hey, we've got to have this, we've got to have this, we've got to have this.
And they just kept trying to build it up because, hey, you know, it's great.
It's the only war we've got.
We might as well make the most of it.
Thank God most military men don't think that way.
There are some that do.
But I would hopefully think that most of them don't.
I think if you talk to most military men, they'll tell you that they're the first ones that really don't want to fight.
And that is if they've seen any fighting at all.
And I think over the, as it continued, they realized that it had gotten out of hand, and they were trying to do something about it, and they didn't know how to do it.
It was like they'd got it all started,
Now where are we going with it and how are we going to get out of it and still save face and still try to accomplish the things that we set out to do?
The first thing was to prevent the takeover of South Vietnam from the communists.
Was it really communists or was it just a revolution between North Vietnam and South Vietnam?
I guess it would have been okay if Chinese weapons and Russian weapons and stuff like that hadn't got involved, and then we hadn't got involved, and we just let them fight on our own.
But other people got involved, so we got involved too.
It's always a lot better to fight a war on somebody else's ground than fight it on yours.
Okay, when you went back for your second tour, were you involved in any way with the Cambodian invasion in 1972?
I sat in Saigon for 31 days while the invasion of Cambodia was going on.
The only indirect way that I got involved with the Cambodian invasion was that we had done some recon in the Parrot Peak area about four months before the invasion.
And that was the only way.
I didn't get directly involved with the invasion of Cambodia other than to do some recon.
What do you think?
President Nixon was right in invading Cambodia and extending the war beyond Vietnam, or do you think it was a bad move?
I think it was a couple years too late.
It wasn't only Cambodia that the North Vietnamese...
had supply dumps and everything.
If we were going to invade Cambodia, why didn't we do Cambodia, Laos, and why didn't we do North Vietnam?
Why didn't we do it all?
I think he was talked into doing it
high-ranking military officers from the South Vietnamese government, plus us, to push that back.
Or maybe the South Vietnamese told him that, hey, if you'll take care of these things, then when you start your withdrawal, then we can take care of everything else on our own.
I don't know.
I know that Cambodia had a lot of storage areas.
I think it was a good move.

militarily to go in and knock out supply dumps and destroy troops where they no longer had a sanctuary where they could they could run to and then stick their noses and their tongues out at you you know back across the river and say nanny nanny boo boo you can't come and get me you know uh when you find a situation like this or you you fight these kind of battles
You know, you're limited in what you can do if the other guy can just duck back across the border.
It was the same thing with the 38th Parallel or whatever it was at the Yalu River in Korea.
You know, for their MiGs to dash back across the Yalu River and us not being able to pursue them was stupid.
You know, they can come down south all they wanted to and shoot everything up and dash back across the river, and we was...
either getting guys busted or slapped the wrist or sent them back to Japan just because they couldn't go back across the river, and they were severely punished if they did do that.

And for us to make arbitrary penetrations across into Cambodia or Laos to chase some gooks that have been shooting at us all day long, and now it's nighttime and they want to go camp out across the river, you know, that's stupid.
If you're going to fight a war, then fight it.

And that's one of the reasons why we couldn't, you know, you can win the battles, but you can't win the war because you're so limited because of political situations that dictate to you on how you're going to fight your enemy.
All right.
Earlier you said when you were in Tet that in the combat zone and in the fire zone you didn't have to call and ask.
You know, you knew you could fight.
Did this having to call and request to get in the firefight
occurred while you were there or had it occurred while you were stateside?
No, that started when I came back in the end of 1968 there was a lot of changes that took place over there I guess because when I got back over in country in 1970 it was different.
A lot of your major units
were standing down like the 4th Infantry Division was getting ready to break up and come back home.
And they were infusing a lot of their troops into units that were going to stay.
So they were already starting their withdrawal.
They didn't go out and really do search and destroy missions anymore.
They stayed pretty close to the highways and just seemed like they didn't want to fight.
And the American soldiers didn't want to fight.
And one of the things that we had to do in the Anke area there for quite a while is we had to call up the district advisor and say, hey, we're in this area.
We see people carrying weapons, and they're going this way.
Can we engage them?
We had it before in 68.
If you saw people wearing black pajamas carrying weapons...
then they were the enemy.
Now, in 1970, we don't know who they are.
We got to call and get permission to engage them.
Now, if they turned around and engaged us, then we could engage them.
So I guess there were a lot of American units that got engaged first, and then they engaged the enemy.
It was, you know, question this, question that.
It was a different thing.
The two years changed the thing in South Vietnam.
What happened there while I was gone, I don't know.
I was comfortable being a military man in 1967 and 68 when I was in Vietnam.
And I was a good soldier.
And I was a good soldier in 1970 and 71.
And I did basically the same things once I got back into it again.
But the rules of engagement had changed, and the feeling of the military in South Vietnam, U.S. and Arvin, had changed.
And it was just, you couldn't really put your finger on it, but you could feel it.
It was finally like somebody had realized, hey, we got us a no-win situation here.
You know?
We're not.
We're winning the fights, and we're getting our body count, and we're doing this and we're doing that, and we're still losing guys.
Where's the final objective?
People were starting to realize, what's the final objective?
We're not going to be allowed to win this thing.
And I think a lot of your senior NCOs and your senior officers were starting to realize that.
So what they were trying to do is protect...
and really not engage.
Because if you don't engage the enemy, then you don't get shot at and you don't get people hurt.
How were you treated, first of all, when you came home in 68?
Did you come home as a unit, as y'all had went over there as a unit, or did you come back as an individual?
I was medevaced, so I came back on a hospital plane.
And of course, when we landed in San Francisco, we didn't go through the normal airport or anything like that.
We went into a military base there in San Francisco.
We stayed on military aircraft when I got to Martin Army Hospital in Fort Hood.
So I didn't see a bunch of civilians.
I stayed around.
I was hooked up completely with the military.
Never had much to do with civilians as far as the 20 years that I spent in the military.
I heard a lot of guys say that when they come home that they got spit on and they had stuff thrown at them and things like that.
I never had anything like that happen to me.
I had some in-laws and some cousins and stuff like that ask me what I thought about the involvement of South Vietnam.

course being pro-military like I was I just told him what I thought used to in the military you could put your uniform on and go downtown and people would slap you on the back and and the military guy was proud to wear his uniform you can get you wearing a uniform walking into a cafe when I went into the military would get you a free cup of coffee
because that's what people thought about veterans and people that served in the armed forces.
Nowadays, I think it's a very rare thing, unless you're around a military base, that you'll see guys

in uniform used to it was a regulation that when you travel by civilian airline you had to travel with your uniform on if you were military now they don't care they let you go anywhere you want to in civilian clothes as long as you report into duty with your uniform on so to me that's wrong i think if you're in the military you ought to wear your uniform when you travel
I don't care if the civilian public like it or not.
That's an obligation that you owe yourself and the military because you're there with them.
I don't know.
I think it's a sad situation because I think the civilian people ought to sit back and think all through history.
And I don't care which war they're talking about.
I don't care if it's Korea.
I don't care if it was Chesty Puller down in Havana, Cuba in the early 1900s.
Think where the United States of America would be today if you didn't have veterans.
What do you think the civilian population was thinking while, especially after Tet, while you were in Vietnam?
What was their attitude?
Well,
I don't know what they were thinking, and quite frankly, I didn't care.
Things were so hot and heavy and busy, we really didn't think about what the civilians were doing.
After a while, that was about the same time that Jane Fonda started all her crap, and Joan Baez and some of these other people.
And the only comments that you'd have are, gee, I'd like to see her for just a few minutes.
or wish she was here on receiving into some of this crap.
And I'd like for her to be here so I could explain to her why we're in this country.

You know, she talks about the bombing of North Vietnam, but she never walked through a village in South Vietnam and saw little kids with legs missing or arms missing or walked into a village right after the VC had been there and taken care of the village chief and his kids and the teachers and stuff like that.
She never done that.
She never had the opportunity to do that.
I just wish that I could have shown all that to her.
Um,
What do you think the military needs to learn from Vietnam?
One of the first things that we knew before we even went into South Vietnam, don't get involved in a war on an Asian land mass.
I guess three reasons.
One is it costs too much money.
It's not politically sound.
And if you don't have the complete backing of the country, you're going to lose men for no reason because you're not going to win.

those three things and it's unfortunate because they're good fighters they've been at it all their lives you know but they can be beat if it came to that they could be beat and it doesn't have to be done with nuclear weapons it can be done with conventional warfare but if the one thing that I would tell

the government of the United States, that if you're going to commit American soldiers to do something, don't tie their hands behind their back and tell them that you want them to win and then stand back and let them win.
Okay.
You talked about the bombing of North Vietnam, Bowling Thunder.
Do you think it was effective?
Yeah, I think to an extent a lot of it was effective.
I think there was a lot of misdirected targets.
I think there was a lot of bombing raids that didn't hit anything because they were afraid to hit civilian areas.
And
You know, when you do bombing on that scale, then you're gonna have to accept a certain amount of civilian casualties.
